content: The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" includes provisions for improving policies related to advance directives, Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making, and increasing awareness of end-of-life planning. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Section 1866(f) of the Social Security Act to include the content of advance directives in medical records and provide individuals with the opportunity to discuss related issues. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Section 1866(f) of the Social Security Act to include advance directive content in medical records and allow individuals to discuss related issues with a trained professional. Providers must honor valid advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those executed within the state. Providers must give effect to valid advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those executed within the state, preempting any inconsistent state laws. This does not override state laws that offer greater portability or deference to a patient's wishes. The provisions of this paragraph preempt any State law inconsistent with them, but do not override laws offering greater portability or deference to a patient's wishes. Medicaid regulations are also amended to include advance directives in a prominent part of the individual's current medical record. The text chunk adds provisions for honoring advance directives executed outside the state, allowing providers to presume validity unless proven otherwise. It also clarifies that this does not authorize treatment prohibited by the state's laws. The text chunk clarifies that advance directives executed outside the state are valid, preempting any inconsistent state laws. It also specifies that it does not override state laws providing greater portability or deference to a patient's wishes. Effective dates for the amendments are outlined for provider agreements under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. The text chunk specifies the effective dates for provider agreements under title XVIII of the Social Security Act and State plans under title XIX. The amendments apply to agreements entered into, renewed, or extended after a specified date set by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, not exceeding 1 year after the enactment of the Act. The text chunk specifies the extension of the effective date for state law amendments under title XIX of the Social Security Act. State plans must meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments made by the Act, but will not be considered non-compliant solely for failing to meet these requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter beginning after the close of the first regular session of the State legislature that begins after the date of enactment. The text chunk specifies the extension of the effective date for state law amendments under title XIX of the Social Security Act. State plans must meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments made by the Act, but will not be considered non-compliant solely for failing to meet these requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter beginning after the close of the first regular session of the State legislature that begins after the date of enactment. In the case of a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year of the session is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature. SEC. 3. Medicare coverage of end-of-life planning consultation during initial preventive physical examination. Medicare coverage of end-of-life planning consultation includes discussions on advance directives, situations where they are important, and the benefits of developing a comprehensive end-of-life plan. The importance of advance directives in end-of-life planning is emphasized, including the need for updating such plans as health changes. Resources for understanding state requirements and designating a surrogate decision maker are also discussed. The willingness of physicians to follow these directives is considered. The amendments made by this section regarding advance directives and surrogate decision makers will apply to preventive physical examinations starting January 1, 2009. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making and hospice care, providing consumer information about advance directives, end-of-life services, and hospice care. SEC. 5. INCREASING AWARENESS OF END-OF-LIFE PLANNING by adding a new part to the Public Health Service Act for programs to increase awareness of advance directive planning issues, including advance directive education campaigns. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for end-of-life care, explain the importance of advance directives, and educate the public about hospice and palliative care. Grants will be awarded to support this campaign. The Secretary will use funds to award grants for education campaigns on advance directives, hospice, and palliative care. $25,000,000 is authorized for this purpose.
